thread: Not allowed entry without a resident's permit?
post:
36 years of living in Switzerland and France... often flying in and out of Geneva, I've never EVER been asked to produce my resident permit.   
It's only since moving our principle residence to France that I've started to carry my passport about with me as I cross the border regularly (I gave no other form of id), but haven't been asked to show it at the border since Schengen came into force.  
As far as I recall apart from at the airport the only other time I've been asked to show it has been once or twice at the bank when withdrawing money at the counter.   
As aSwissInTheUS rightly says, you do not have to carry it, but must be able to produce it within a reasonable delay.

thread: Bags and Swiss retail
post:
Because I buy multiple fruits and veggies at once.    
E.g. I buy 10 tomatoes, 10 kiwis, 20 apricots and 10 onions.     
I get two bags.  
I put the tomatoes in one bag, weigh them, put their sticker on the bag. 
I then put the kiwis in the other bag, weigh that, put their sticker on the tomato bag and add the kiwis to the tomato bag.  
I then put the apricots in the other - now empty again - bag, weigh that, put their sticker on the tomato bag and add the apricots to the tomato bag.    
I then weigh the onions in the second - now once again empty - bag, and put their sticker on the bag.    
This way I have only two bags - at most - for all my fruits and veg, with all the stickers on the bag/s and no fruit/veg rolling around at any time.  
It would be impossible to put all that stuff on the scale without a bag, even only one fruit type at a time, it would be rolling around everywhere and I'd be wasting people's time collecting the rolling-around fruit while people who also want to buy veg and fruit are waiting behind me.   
So - if you only have 2-5 or so fruit/veg items to weigh, weighing them before bagging probably won't turn into a hassle. But trying that with larger amounts seems too much hassle.

thread: Does Switzerland need new fighter jets?
post:
You are much closer to the truth for Switzerland than you'd ever know! We lost all our ground attack experts when the Hunter was retired at the end of 1994 and then our reconnaisance squadron flying the Mirage IIIRS was disbanded after 2003. The UAVs and Super Puma/Cougar helicopters will never be able to match the insight we had with the recon Mirages with their sensors and infra-red radars (FLIR).   
These days our Hornets have no specific air to ground weapons except for the on board cannon. Bombs and rockets disappeared in the mid 1990s when the Hunter was retired. Of course, the wiring and pylons are all available, but the doctrine is air-to-air these days.

thread: The end of banking secrecy for foreigners
post:
Sorry by saying  artificial that is why i put ''...i did not mean anything for Switzerland as a sovereign state which i full respect and its people. I meant ''artificial'' in terms of neutrality and financial aspect. For example even during recent history Greece wanted to stay neutral during the WWII...nobody respected that and it was attacked by both Italy and GErmany. However nobody touched Switzerland because everybody had advantages both Nazi Germans (use of financial reserves, railway system)with the tolerance of Swiss people ( i don't raise the point whether this was ethical or not) and the allies. But coming to today because somebody mentioned that they keep taxes from the money being deposited in Swiss banks. Well this is not entirely true, they keep a percentage of the interest which is minimal. The problem with Swiss banks is that they never ask where do money come from. Having lived in NL, UK when i deposited a relatively large amount of money within 5 days (in NL) i got a notice from the tax office to go and explain where i found the money. This is to prevent money laundering etc..in Switzerland this is not the case (at least to my knowledge). 
So something has to be done in terms of this aspect.  Moreover, having the benefits of a close association with EU while not following the norms is also not appropriate e.g. (minimal taxation across EU, subsidies) etc.  But having said that, i do recognise even within EU there are so many differences taking into example my home country which follows absolutely no Eu norms and the situation led Greece where it is now.

thread: Pizzeria in Greifensee serves free food
post:
In Basel there is a bread/cake shop with the same idea:       
The collect bread, sandwiches, cakes, etc. from other bakeries at the end of the day, and sell them the next day, as still-good "fresh from yesterday" food, at very much reduced prices.   
Anyone who cannot afford to pay can take a post-it voucher off the fridge, and use that to pay. Anyone who can afford to pay a bit more can buy a post-it voucher and stick it on the fridge for someone else.   
A tiny place with a super-friendly atmosphere.  And just three or four chairs, so one can stop for coffee, too.

thread: "For the couple and the family" initiative
post:
shows the absolute numbers for the various household types.       is on couples with at least one kid below 7 years. The grass-green pie represents the traditional model with a single earner, the darker-green dual earner with a clear main-earner (one with  100% workload, the other works anything between 0% and 100%). Their combined share, though  shrinking, didn't change thaaat much, it's still about 3 in 4 households  considered. Both working part time is the orange pie.      (excerpt from page 12 of  )  shows that single parent homes have way much lower average income (40%  of which is transfer icnoem to begin with) than any other household  group, which shows why kids are the poverty risk number one. The  "Obligatorische  Abzüge" (mandatory deductions) mentioned in the chart include payments  for children and ex-wife  after divorce, "Transfereinkommen" means all forms of social security  income including AHV and individual social help and transfer income for  the children. Interestingly available average income is roughly the same  for all groups except for singles and single parent homes (is perhaps  the number of children by quite a  bit a function of available income?).   
Single earner in my mind isn't absolte. For me this includes households where one earns, say, 15% or less of the total income.

thread: Swiss annual deflation now at (-)1.4%
post:
Something to ask bank before signing, but it sounds more like retail client with massive mortgage situation, rather than small-guy-with-secondary-apartment type.   
I look on CHF mortgage in my case like this - if CHF would go up, it's not the best thing for mortgage (no increased costs, but no gains either), BUT - all my & fiancee's remaining earnings would go up, at least on global scale (which boils down to local somehow, eventually, even if just a bit). Those are of course much more than monthly down payments of secondary residence.   
If CHF would go down, our net worth would suffer, but at least there is no additional hit in increased monthly payments compared to EURO mortgage.   
For people in Geneva, strong CHF means real savings since so many things can be facilitated across the border, from which you are never more than few kms.    
(there are nasty consequences of strong CHF in employment part, but since there is no real job security anyway, this part doesn't give me creeps).

thread: Good book about Swiss politics, especially about relationship with EU?
post:
I don't know of any book that is up to date, and the situation is continuously developing so no book will ever be up to date.   
I think reading the newspapers is best. Ideally read different newspapers with slightly different biases (for example NZZ and Tagi) so as to get a broader perspective.   
Tagi used to be my favourite paper but I've moved on to being more an NZZ type of person. I like the low key understatements, the holistic projections and the thinking between the lines. Occasionally rereading another newsppaer is necessary though to keep some sort of check on the bias.

thread: French frontaliers debt grows
post:
St Croix is quite a different story actually- and it industry which collapsed in the 70s, was much more based on musical boxes, record players and cameras, including the famous BOLEX.   
The watch making industry was much more important in my Valley- where about about a dozen watch making and parts manufacturers closed in the 70s- as well as a massive knitting machine factory, the best in the world for over a Century- as they didn't see the Japanese arriving with new technology. It was a tragedy for the area- I grew up here in the 50s and 60s- when all those industries were booming, watch makers, but also hands, ébauches, and all sort of parts, and also several engineering firms, and as said, a massive knitting machine factory exporting all over the world.   
 But some of the young watch-makers picked themselves up, and decided, very wisely and cleverly, that the only way to bring back watch-making was to invest in very high quality top of the range watches. They took a huge risk- but it paid off- with the highest quality label attached. One of those was the son of an Italian immigrant- I take my hat off to him for all he has achieved. And the authorities also realised it was paramount to diversify.   
Yacek. it is tough for you and I am sorry. But can you really talk about a 'mindset' in a negative way. Vaud on its own is owed over one million CHF by France for frontaliers. That is not peanuts. And each unemployed person and their family cost the community millions too- as well as affects a whole range of cultural and social factors too. As hard as it is on you, can you not imagine why it makes sense to employ local people first, and that this is not anti frontaliers or foreign workers? Bonne chance.

thread: News about weed legalization in some CH cities
post:
In Luzern at least, it's still illegal, but penalties have been reduced to an on the spot fine of 100CHF fro small amounts, if you get caught. ( )   
Some locations are rife with it and you can smell it in the air, parks by the lake in summer for example, certain bars and clubs are happy to tolerate skinning up inside so long as it's taken outside to smoke, certain clubs that allow smoking may tolerate it inside (Although it may depend on who organised the night and who the security is).  TBH, you can tell by the crowd who frequent the place.  Police rarely seem to bother such spots and turn a blind eye, or maybe people see them coming.   
I've heard of fines delivered closer to the town and around the station, so maybe they're just concerned with family and tourist spots.

The full video proves that the kurdish protester who get run over had previously attacked the car with sticks, beating on it. thread: Swiss airline prices to rise
post:
I've just booked Swiss ZH to Amsterdam for a long weekend, only 119.00 chufs return Friday to Monday in November with carry on bag only which I think is pretty cheap. But for the first time I've noticed the extra cost for hold luggage, 19.00 per leg. I don't think that's too bad if it means that carry on fairs are as cheap as I just got. (I opted for a case on the return for my shopping  )   
But also I noticed for the first time they are charging extra to pay by CC. Have they always done that? 11.00 chufs for 138.00 fair seems really high. So I paid by Post card which is still free.   
Even with a price rise, I will still fly as much as possible with them for the convenience and reliability.

thread: Switzerland ranked world safest country
post:
Pfefferspray  ein legales Mittel zur Selbstverteidigung   
Nicht nur Frauen, auch Polizisten benutzen Pfefferspray. Dessen Handhabung erlernen Polizisten in der Ausbildung. Bild kaposz 
Nicht nur Frauen, auch Polizisten benutzen Pfefferspray. Dessen Handhabung erlernen Polizisten in der Ausbildung. Bild kaposz 
Nach der Vergewaltigung in Emmen fühlen sich viele Frauen nicht mehr sicher. Führen sie einen Pfefferspray in der Handtasche mit, können sie sich im Ernstfall wehren. 
von Irene Lustenberger     
Am Abend des 21. Juli reisst ein Unbekannter in Emmen eine 26-jährige Frau vom Velo und vergewaltigt sie in einem Waldstück. Seither ist das Opfer vom Hals abwärts gelähmt. 
Der Vorfall macht betroffen und weckt vor allem bei Frauen Angst. Deshalb erstaunt es nicht, dass Pfeffersprays in Luzern und Umgebung seither gefragt sind.   
«Jede Person über 18 Jahren darf einen Pfefferspray besitzen und mit sich führen», bestätigt David Mynall, Mediensprecher der Kantonspolizei Schwyz. Aufgrund des Wirkstoffs sei Pfefferspray keine Waffe, Tränengas hingegen schon. «Pfefferspray greift einzig die Schleimhäute an, Tränengas wirkt aber auf die Atemwege. Dies kann für die betroffene Person lebensgefährlich werden», führt Mynall aus. Trotzdem dürfe Pfefferspray nur zur Selbstverteidigung oder zur Abwehr eines Angriffs eingesetzt werden. «Wird der Spray willkürlich eingesetzt, kann die betroffene Person eine Anzeige wegen Tätlichkeiten machen», so der Mediensprecher.    
Den vollständigen Artikel lesen Sie im «March-Anzeiger» und im «Höfner Volksblatt» vom Montag.

thread: EasyJet Gatwick to Basel turned back today
post:
In the bad old days of Dan-Air, a distant relative of mine was flying a charter flight from Gatwick to Turkey. There was a short cut through the DDR airspace, but which needed prior permission to use.    
The following was the pure Biggles style of flying.    
Second officer: "erm captain, there's a Mig on my side & he's waving at me."  
Captain : "yep there's one this side waving too. I think he wants us to follow him down."    
The Dan-Air office had neglected to receive permission to overfly the DDR!    
They landed, gave the Turkish workers a meal on board, and suffered some gentle interrogation from the local Stasi.  
Second officer said, "They were getting a bit nasty, and then I passed the Polo mints around and they became a bit more relaxed"    
His mother was furious, "Last week you had a fire in the cockpit, don't lie to me, I read it in the DM. And now this happens!"    
Biggles: "Yes, well, that was all last week Mum."

thread: Switzerland in top 10 in 2012 PISA survey (mathematics)
post:
This is true-all tests of educational achievement are flawed.  There's actually been a lot of research on the PISA tests regarding methodology and country-specific flaws.  These studies suggest that, more than anecdotal evidence, there are systemic flaws in test implementation that can strongly influence country scores.  These, unfortunately, tend to lag far behind the PISA results (for obvious reasons).   
From a critical review of the 2000 PISA:   
"The issue of response bias due to pupils having already left school, by the date of the survey, may be expected to be even more serious in countries where 15 is the age when obligatory full-time schooling ends as, for example, in many parts of Switzerland and Germany, but much depends on the survey's coverage of part-time vocational colleges.  Vocational colleges in these countries were sampled in respect of their 15 year olds; pupil-response rates have been published for Germany, but reached only a disappointing 44% (compared to 86% for the inquiry as a whole in that country)."

post:
I confess to having only read the 20 Min article quickly, but I must have missed the part where the US Embassy called the police.  Rather, the article suggests that the police called the US Embassy to confirm that it was ok to permit the flowers to remain but only after the police had conducted the control.       
Given the current situation across much of Europe, only an absolute fool would be surprised about being subject to police scrutiny when approaching any western embassy under the circumstances described in the article.  The police would have no doubt taken exactly the same action if the flowers had been laid in front of the French or Belgian embassies.   
Oh, and it is only a matter of time before IZRS is found to have been funneling monies used in the funding of terrorist activity.  There is simply no comparison whatsoever between drawing a cartoon and knowingly financing a "revolution", not to mention openly recruiting jihadists, in another country.

thread: There's gold in them thar hills
post:
Austria is removing a large part of its 280 tonne gold reserves from the UK and transferring it home to Austria and to Switzerland:   
Current locations of gold reserves: 
UK: 80% 
Austria: 17% 
Switzerland: 3%   
Future locations: 
UK: 30% 
Austria: 50% 
Switzerland: 20%   
The Austrian Accounting Office has criticized storing so much of the country's gold in one country, the UK, and the new strategy is to distribute storage risk better. This could also be interpreted as a vote of confidence in Switzerland.

thread: Shooting in Switzerland
post:
This is absolutely spot on!      
When I lived in NY and worked in the Federal court system (decades ago), I was fingerprinted and had to undergo a VERY thorough background check by the FBI that took some months to be completed. I eventually received governmental security clearance at the Federal level, and  I was allowed to apply for a firearm license, but there was further scrutiny. I passed muster and obtained a license to carry a small firearm, which I did for several years. The only occasion(s) on which I ever fired that gun was at bi-yearly target practice at the police range -- thankfully! I was also happy to give it up in the end because, somehow, having it became a burden.

thread: Marriage in Swiss
post:
The electorate are some millions of People, which means everybody above 18 .  There however are SEVEN Federal Councillors who are the Federal Government "in corpore". They are elected into Office by the congress, which means Senate (Ständerat) and House of Representatives (Nationalrat) in Joint Session (Vereinigte Bundesversammlung). The members of the two Federal Parliaments and the members of the Cantonal Parliaments and the Cantonal Governments are however directly elected by the People     
Switzerland fairly early adopted the battle cry of the French Revolution

thread: Gurlitt collection of 'Nazi Art' bequeathed to Bern museum
post:
Today in Bern is the Onion Market day, a sort of Oktoberfest without the beer and thrilling rides.    
It is also announced that today the decision will be made on whether to accept the multi-million legacy of Gurlitts junior who died in Munich. The controversy centres around any tax the Gurlitt estate will have to pay the Bavarian tax office. Another possible problem is if any Jewish relatives pop up and claim that a painting belonged to their old relative.    
Info: Gurlitt's father was high up in the Nazi party and was an art dealer, his collection passed to his son, who kept it hidden to avoid taxes. Gurlitt has bequeathed in his Will the massive art collection to the Bern art museum, on condition it be kept and displayed together. So a big expense for Bern is forewarned..

thread: "Switzerland, a country that works" - Washington Times article
post:
I think what makes Switzerland so special is that people do get on across linguistic and religious boundaries. The individual cantons are traditionally pretty homogenous and thus people don't feel threatened by the other lot taking over thei homes and their way of life. But between cantons there is a strong will to work together for the greater good. sure, there is a lot of mud slinging and the Röstigraben rears its ugly head, but at the end of the day they bury their differences and get the job done.   
This is in contrast to the US where there are often real vile differences between red and blue states and one lot will sometimes think God wants them to force the other lot to do things their way rather than being prepared to live and let live.   
So the swiss way is that if you gon into the other guy's canton, you do things his way, and if he comes into yours you expect him to do things your way.   
I can imagine that if there were say,a Muslim canton in Switzerland, then you'd still get the diatribe but they'd respect that canton's right to reverse the diatribe in their own canton and neither side would think badly of the other for it.

thread: Swiss baby dies after being forgotten by parent in car
post:
I forget a lot of things but I can not imagine forgetting a child and going to work for 8+ hours.  But then again, my job is stay at home mom and the kids are my job.  Now,  I have purposefully left my babies in the car when they were asleep - most times parked in my attached garage to my house with the baby monitor in the car.  If not, I would be within eyesight of the car and check on them, and if the weather was too hot, I would bring them inside.     
It is tragic and will haunt the guilty their entire lives, I can't imagine it.  However, even after reading much of the article mentioned, I am not sure how I should look differently at these incidents.   
ETA:    OK, I will give someone the benefit of the doubt that maybe you forget if you do a quick pop into a store. My former neighbor told me once she did this as her mother had been visiting and she had had some time out alone without the baby.  The next time out she "forgot" - but only for 5 minutes before she was in a panic and returned to her car.  But if you are gone for several hours, I don't see how you could forget your child in the car.    
I guess that is the one benefit of never having had family or others around to take care of my kids for me - I always knew I had to have them with me.  When kid # 3 came into the family, I used to do a "kid count" with my kids before driving away, especially if it was too quiet in the back!  It's turned into a bit of a joke and we still do it sometimes today, with the kids who are 10, 8 and 5.

thread: UBS is not accepting US citizens to open bank accounts?!?!
post:
all of the above advice to go to the offices in the city is spot on, we have never had any trouble at all with UBS and we are also US citizens.   
fyi, if anyone were to actually have a frank discussion with an honest Swiss banker (yes, they do exist), they would be very open that the Swiss banking industry was knowingly helping US citizens hide taxable income from the US authorities for years upon years, and the fines that have been assessed are just the tip of the iceberg.  you do not have to like the US policy of taxing citizenship rather than residency (and, candidly, what kind of expat WOULD like it), but the Swiss banking industry has been aware of the rules since Hector was a pup and the only thing that upsets the Swiss banking industry now is the disclosure requirement (since the disclosure requirement compels the banks to disclose behavior that has gone on for decades).

thread: VAT and Import: Buying abroad might become more expensive
post:
As mostly, I agree with Tom   Really, so what? 
Here is why, I for one welcome our new tax overloard.       
It is for all goods send by a company that makes at least a CHF 100k turnover with sales in Switzerland. Such a company will get a Swiss VAT number and has to charge VAT at purchase time. Reference: Federal Council Proposal.   
Why is it good? It means that the silly post surcharges and administration fees for purchases over CHF 63, and CHF 200 respectively will be history.    
Who cares about the CHF 5 VAT. None. Who cares about the post surgarches? Everyone. Reference: EF.   
Now they have to implement the same procedure for duty.

thread: Julie Andrews - honorary citizen Gstaad
post:
What I meant was, the federal government produces the passport, i.e., they have the contract with the company that produces the passport. La Suisse existe, mais la citoyenneté suisse dépend du droit de cité cantonal et de la bourgeoisie communale.  
A foreigner cannot naturalise in Switzerland without the permission of the federal government. So, because this honorary naturalisation was not authorised by the federal government, the naturalisation is not valid.  
C.f. LN Art 12 §2 "La naturalisation n'est valable que si une autorisation fédérale a été accordée par l'office compétent."

thread: Rules for election posters and promotion in Switzerland
post:
Hi, I'm trying to find out the rules and regulations for Swiss (and also German) elections when it comes to advertising, promotion of candidates, putting up posters etc. In my country posters can only be put up 4 weeks before an election, but then it's a free for all with every accessible telegraph pole covered and sometimes traffic lights and other sign-age blocked. They are usually pretty big, roughly 3 - 4 ft (90-120 cm) by 2 - 3 foot. These posters can get blown down in heavy weather and sometimes end up strewn across streets, in fields etc.   
The bigger parties have large budgets for postering and promotion, leaving the independents and smaller parties at a disadvantage. There are penalties for putting posters up early but they are rarely enforced.   
So if anyone has answers (even better for Germany also) or can point me to a site or resource with this info I'd be grateful.   
 - Are posters for election candidate allowed in Switzerland? 
 - Are there restrictions as to when / where posters can be placed? 
 - Are there restictions on size / dimensions?  
 - Do they have to be removed by a certain time period after an election? 
 - Are there any penalties for breaches of the rules?   
TIA

thread: Voting tomorrow
post:
You are much closer to the truth for Switzerland than you'd ever know! We lost all our ground attack experts when the Hunter was retired at the end of 1994 and then our reconnaisance squadron flying the Mirage IIIRS was disbanded after 2003. The UAVs and Super Puma/Cougar helicopters will never be able to match the insight we had with the recon Mirages with their sensors and infra-red radars (FLIR).   
These days our Hornets have no specific air to ground weapons except for the on board cannon. Bombs and rockets disappeared in the mid 1990s when the Hunter was retired. Of course, the wiring and pylons are all available, but the doctrine is air-to-air these days.

thread: Minimum attendance in Swiss referendum
post:
Our sister republic adopted democracy comparatively early and they have some stuff in their system, which many other countries avoided later on (e.g. the Electoral College, single-winner voting systems where it does not seem fit etc.) .   there is a need for adjustment it would probably help to discard of this strange cult about the "founding fathers" and actually clean up the system so that voting actually makes any difference.            How generous... And why exactly should organised moral concerns be more important than personal ones? This makes the system worse, not better. It introduces arbitrary discrimination.    
And if there are many such excuses, why even introduce this system? I still fail to see a reason to force people to do something they obviously don't want to. Making weaseling out easier is not exactly making a strong point on why such a system is needed in the first place.

There were, before 1940,  a number of farmers parties and a number of small business parties, who then merged into the BGB Party (Bürger/Gewerbe/Bauern >  Citizens/small-trade/farmers) and later renamed into SVP. The SVP was centrist and left of the FDP until Mr Blocher took over and moved the SVP to the Far Right. Many important SVP leaders like Ulrich Giezendanner resist this up to now. thread: There will be a 14 days cooling off period on new contracts
post:
Yesterday it was announced by the Bundesrat (Government) there  will be  a change to the Obligations Recht (OR)          
In future, certain contracts entered into over the Internet, or by telephone, will have a 14 day cooling off period. There are items specifically excluded, such as travel tickets and perishable food stuff. This will bring Swiss law into line with other European countries.    
Please post here when something definite is found.

thread: Increase in college tuition fees
post:
Hello,   
I've been selected for a masters at EPFL. But recently I got to know about a plan by swiss government to increase the tuition fees. My plan is to work in a lab at EPFL to support my expenses because my parents can not afford it. The amount I get by working there will be marginally enough to support my expenses. But if the proposed increase happens, I'll be in trouble.   
I was able to find these two documents regarding the debate in the parliament. 
Debate on 06/03/2014 :  
Debate on 03/10/2013 :      
Here is my questions, 
I read these documents using the google translator.  But it's not much clear. At one point it says  
"the fees may not exceed three times the amount ".  
Have I understood that correctly ? If this is the case, I might be able to cover my tuition fees somehow. But if they increase it by a large factor (like 10 times the current one) to match US tuition fees, I'll be in big trouble.      ]         PLEASE REPLY - I BADLY NEED TO CLARIFY THIS ASAP   
Thank you   
PS :  
1. When I work in the lab, I'll pay 200 chf every month as taxes. 
2. EPFL do not guarantee that the fees will remain constant after enrolling.

thread: Angy Burri R.I.P. legendary Lucerne artist & musician.
post:
There was a time when country music, Harleys and being a fan of America was cool in Switzerland. Angy helped to make it happen.   
Angy Burri achieved quite a celebrity status in the 80's and beginning 90's in Switzerland.  He lived the "American Indian" spirit and created a public life around it.  Schweizer Illustrate wrote many cover stories on him.  People came far and wide to see him sing and he was especially loved by Harley Davidson fans and country fans in general. He was portrayed as a big man with a gentle soul.   
Thanks for the good memories, Angy.

thread: GMO food: any laws in Switzerland?
post:
Switzerland is not in the EU, but enacts many of the same laws. Part of the argument for food here being so expensive is that the CH has regulated a higher standard than the EU. Bio (combination of organic/freerange etc) is common, and we don't have corn syrup in everything.   
CH also has power stations, electricity and internet. We don't all have our own cow herd and the country is known for it's chemical and pharmaceutical industries.    
btw, when most people refer to Switzerland as clean, they mean in this way.

thread: Minder initiative: first consequences companies
post:
Minder is not about preventing other people from making tons of money. But it's about creating more transparency and giving shareholders a say in what a company can do with what is after all their (the shareholders') money. It's the people who are against that, ie, the people who think that a board, once elected, can do what it wants with other people's money( a phenomenon otherwise known as socialism), who are trying to paint that in a brush of being jealous about what good performers are making. If a CEO is genuinely giving that added value to a company, the shareholders would be stupid not to reward him for that. But this is about the "other CEOs make big money, I am a CEO, therefore I am entitled to that money too" attitude.    
1:12 on the other hand is just the nanny state adding to the list of things people aren't allowed to do with their own money. Putting the two in the same pot is missing the point somewhat.

thread: Pisa Results Educational Standards Switzerland
post:
This is true-all tests of educational achievement are flawed.  There's actually been a lot of research on the PISA tests regarding methodology and country-specific flaws.  These studies suggest that, more than anecdotal evidence, there are systemic flaws in test implementation that can strongly influence country scores.  These, unfortunately, tend to lag far behind the PISA results (for obvious reasons).   
From a critical review of the 2000 PISA:   
"The issue of response bias due to pupils having already left school, by the date of the survey, may be expected to be even more serious in countries where 15 is the age when obligatory full-time schooling ends as, for example, in many parts of Switzerland and Germany, but much depends on the survey's coverage of part-time vocational colleges.  Vocational colleges in these countries were sampled in respect of their 15 year olds; pupil-response rates have been published for Germany, but reached only a disappointing 44% (compared to 86% for the inquiry as a whole in that country)."

thread: 4x NO!
post: The aim of the initiative is to put things so that everybody gets the same tax break per child, regardless of what they do with the tax savings. Currently a tax break is given only for children left with commercial daycare providers, so parents with the same number of kids get taxed more heavily, simply because they don't use a commercial daycare provider. The initiative seeks to eliminate that disparity.

thread: "Why the Swiss Scorn the Superrich"
post:
The NY Times has a fine op-ed piece called " Why the Swiss Scorn the Superrich". The writer sums up the Swiss view of its bankers quite well, tolerated but not loved:   "Until the mid-19th century, Switzerland was  poor. My great-grandmother, who grew up in an Alpine valley, often went  hungry; occasionally, she was even forced to eat grass to fill her  belly. Switzerland’s elevation to the ranks of the most prosperous  nations was largely because of its manufacturing industry: watches,  textiles and mechanical engineering.           
It was only after World War II that Switzerland became an important  player in the financial sector. Despite our reputation abroad, that is  probably why banks don’t really figure in our sense of who we are; we  just let them get on with it. Their revenues contributed substantially  to our welfare, but we were never in love with them."

thread: How Neutral is Switzerland?
post:
Let's not exaggerate. General Dufour did NOT order things really, but he had a tremendous influence.    
But yes, a heavy part of the CH constitution IS copied from the USA constitution.   
Also bear in mind that the Liberal Party (FDP) at that time was a kind of government party, as the Katholisch-Konservative Partei (now CVP) .  The Social Democrats were not yet existing but only much later broke away from the liberals. What is not the BGB/SVP then were a number of farmers parties and of parties of small traders. The 7 members of the first federal governments were all Liberals.

thread: The policy of expansion of Switzerland effectively ended...
post:
...after the   498 years ago. After the Swiss were unable to defend Milan against the French on the 13th and 14th of September 1515 an "Eternal Peace" was negotiated between the two parties which held until the invasion of the French Revolutionary Army in Switzerland 1798.       
Besides the influence on the European power relationships, the loss of the battle was also an important step on the path to the   which culminated in a first declaration of Neutrality from the   in 1674.     
One of the participants of the battle was  . Zwingli, surely due to his services on the battlefield, had become convinced mercenary service was immoral. As this was also the stance of the government of Zürich, it allowed him to become Leutpriester at the Grossmünster from where he had big influence on the reformation in Switzerland as well as on other reformists like   who in return is counted by some historians, together with Bucer, as the most influential theologian of the Anglican reformation.     
As the 500 year anniversary of the battle will take place in 2015, preparations for publications and events are currently ongoing. Besides the restauration of the bone house Santa Maria della Neve, where the bones of the fallen mercenaries are stored and a post stamp other projects are planned as well for example a cartoon in three languages with the title "Marignano, what's that?". Two NZZ articles about the planned projects and the driving force behind it, the organisation  , can be found   and  .

thread: Switzerland: the most successful country in the world
post:
Our politics here in Switzerland are tough to beat. We tend not to berate individuals or their characters because most of us know at last someone involved in politics, even if that is the local school overview committee in your local town.    
We more or less get the chance to vote on all the major issues through referendums. Issues  as potentially volatile as the minaret case a few years ago wasn't associated with individual politicians, rather the political parties were the protagonists. Keeping individuals out of both national and international issues does allow the electorate to focus on the issues at hand, rather than being fed a diet of tabloid type sensationalism.    
On the other side, when politicians are left to their own devices, they can make a mess of major issues which would have been better dealt with by referendum. The non bailout of Swissair, or handing UBS billions without consulting taxpayers spring to mind.

I have another aunt who also passed with Leukemia . The pain was so bad and after many consideration she decided to do Euthanasia. I find it normal that one should have that choice of when/where/how to go.....

thread: This Swiss have voted...
post:
The reason that places are empty in April is because literally everything closes down.  For me, this really makes something of a nonsense of the "cold beds" argument.  Naturally mountain lifts need to close for maintenance and to wait for the snow to melt, but where we are they don't open again until July.  All the main hotels and restaurants are shut and most local facilities (e.g. indoor swimming pools etc.) are shut.     
Second homes in Switzerland are really only usable for a very short period of each year.  We are lucky enough to own a second home, which is very much a   to us and as such we use it for more than four months of the year.  I would very much like to use our home more, we also rent ours to contacts we have, but I cannot in good conscience rent a property when the whole place is shut and there is nothing at all to do.  The ghost town problem is created by the Gemeindes themselves, not the second home owners.   
A whole new approach to tourism needs to be adopted if year round tourism is wanted.  At the moment, the tourism industry funds its whole year from the winter season by charging extortionate prices, adds a bit of jam on top from the summer season and simply shuts up shop during the shoulder spring and autumn season.     
If Switzerland wants to do something about "cold beds" then people should be incentivised to rent their properties.  At the moment, a local annual "bed tax" is charged if an owner wishes to rent out his property.  Tax is then paid on the rent earned in addition to the normal deemed rental income tax on any property owned in CH.  When you weigh this up with the costs of advertising the property and processing the rental (cleaning etc.) and the wear and tear on the property then it is no surprise that many people choose not to take the option.   
Naturally I agree that nature and the environment should be preserved, but to a large extent this is already happening.  Most mountain areas which have a high proportion of second homes have already imposed restrictions on new builds specifically for the second home market.

thread: SVP wants Switzerland to terminate the human rights convention...
post:
I am more wondering if you get it... human rights are not "just refugees". We are talking about things like 
- Right to life 
- Freedom from torture 
- Freedom from slavery 
- Right to a fair trial 
- Freedom of speech 
- Freedom of thought, conscience and religion 
and many more.   
The trick with international conventions is that they only work if all take part. If the UK as a security council member would leave is the entire thing not worth the paper it is written on. It is the only time in history that humans agreed in principle what is right and wrong. Nobody claims that the convention is perfect or that all countries are following it - the world simply is far from perfect. But for me is this one of the few true achievements of the UN - most of the stuff they did in the past 60 years was a giant waste of money, but making everyone agree to that basic principle has probably saved more lives than all those people here banging on the refugees think.   
It's a shame that nobody seems to value it...

Well, one guy here also suggested that we have torches located at strategic locations in the stairs because (quote) 'when the power goes off, there won't be any power for the emergency lights either'.   
We're not allowed to light candles in the office (came from Christmas time) as is poses a serious health and safety risk. At least, for some areas, they've seen the light..   
Otherwise, going back on topic to the Zuri West power outage scandal, I can only guess that the medium-voltage network isn't designed with much redundancy in mind or any real ability to safely reconfigure the system if one section fails. If I look at the distribution network within a (non-nuclear)power plant, there is redundancy everywhere; you can always use the switching elements within the network to safely reconfigure the system in case one section fails.

thread: Migros takeover Digitec
post:
Service? At Digitec? Does not exist. I know because I bought all my stuff there... the entire concept of Digitec was "harddiscount" - the electronics version of Aldi - no fancy shops, no high rent, no incompetent sales assistants earning 4-5k standing around doing nothing all day. No or very low stock of products to keep the business lean and avoid the costs to sell old stock for discounted prices. Just a website and a counter manned by an army of students (The students are probably decently paid though because the concept worked and made the company popular). Therefore no service beyond your legal minimum rights, waiting lines to pick stuff up and anything people would possible endure to get a good price.   
The Migros on the other hand is a cooperative that is the exact opposite - high costs, terrible employees in the electronics section, usually outdated stock, uncompetitive prices.   
Bottom line - there is no way that Migros under their own brand would manage to operate like Digitec. They are diametral opposite company cultures... I hope they keep the business independant. Otherwise will it go down in record time. Because nobody went to digitec because of their convenient parking places... if that happens am I sure that somebody will fill in the gap. It is not that hard to copy the concept...

thread: Economist 2012: Zurich most expensive city globally
post:
Not to put too fine a point on it but...what are you smoking?   Value? Hotels? we paid 375chf/night for one TINY hotel room in a pretty run of the mill place, no frills and not scenic. Sure, there was breakfast, but if you're not much of a breakfast person, this isn't a big deal. The company is actually paying my husband 10k /more/ in the US. Unless you're some sort of wage slave in the US who gets promoted to a 100k or more chf pay packet in Switzerland, the win is simply not there.    
The skew is far more than simply 'exchange' rate inequities.

thread: Some complete idiots killed the bear!
post: IMHO, causing a collision with a train is threatening a human's life.  Also, rearing up in front of a bus is a menacing act.  Did you read the article?  Its not like this bear just follows people around like a lost puppy?       If an animal is attacked by another animal, it defends itself.  Many prey animals will actually go so far as to actually attack predator animals preemptively and kill them.  Why is this any different from what was done here?  Further, I would not consider death by mauling a natural cause of death for a human anymore.      This is foolish hyperbole.  We cannot protect ourselves from every danger.  However, we can protect ourselves from a rogue bear.      No, I don't "fail to see the point."  I don't agree with those that believe this one bear had more rights than all the people living in the area, nor with those that assume this decision was made lightly and without considering or trying other options first.      I don't NEED to ask them anything, as they're free to make decisions about their own safety from wild animals themselves.  I think everyone in that area, including the children were aware of that bear and knew what to do.  They obviously also did not feel invincible as they chose to eliminate the bear.      Two deaths are better than one?        I'm actually confident that they probably considered relocation as an option.  If you read the article, several less-than-lethal options were tried; why would they exclude such an obvious option from consideration?        Not just a bit...        You aren't "essentially" saying that, you ARE saying that.  Why don't you travel down there and point to the person you wish dead?  Can't do that?  Then why should it be any easier when the affected person is just an abstract concept?      Again, I'm sure nobody just flipped a coin, saying heads he lives, tails he dies. thread: Austria votes to keep military conscription
post:
There was no surprise at the strong vote to keep the military the way it is. The result came from the weakness of the alternative on the ballot. The alternative was a professional army and a voluntary paid year of service for both men and women. No convincing, realistic recruitment plans were presented for the year of service.    
Many agree that mandatory service for men is quite outdated and quite unnecessary for a neutral country such as Austria. The only military operations in which they participate are those of NATO and the UN, and those are carried out by the professional fraction of the army. However, a major part of the rescue and relief operations are carried out by the military. Additionally, a large number of men (who choose to do a civilian service year instead of military service) provide the workforce of social service organizations such as Caritas (like Spitex) and the Red Cross. How this workforce would be replaced without the mandatory service was very unclear to the voters.    
The vote came from the pragmatism of the Austrian people. Before you can do away with an established labor force, you must have a replacement to continue to provide these vital services. I don't personally like mandatory military service one bit. But I do understand the need to properly reform rather than flippantly abolish the system.

thread: DODIS - Diplomatic Documents of Switzerland
post:
An interesting resource for everyone.   
URL:    
iPhone App:    
The DDS are a research project aiming to edit key documents on Swiss foreign relations.   
The work of the Diplomatic Documents of Switzerland is both academic and practical in nature. The editors provide researchers and practitioners with official sources in printed and digitalised form which are necessary to reconstruct and gain an understanding of the history of Swiss foreign policy.   
The relevant documents are selected and edited by a research group whose members are historians from Swiss universities. It is also responsible for the annotation of the documents.

thread: Do the Swiss charge the asylum seekers for rent?
post:
Well, the topic was about "charging asylum seekers for rent". This is clearly not charged by Swiss authorities whilst their claims are pending ( which means they have an N permit ).   
Rejectees ( therefore technically no longer asylum seekers as far as the Swiss authorities are concerned ) lose their N permits and work rights, and therefore access to lodging ( and other benefits ). They are sent a letter by the Cantonal authorities to surrender their permit and to leave the Canton.   
Those who do not depart become   and depend on churches, charities and emergency shelters ( especially during the colder months ).    
These organisations support the Sans papiers for medical treatment,  , shared bedding, travel tickets and so on as they have exhausted most means to become documented. I was involved in teaching IT literacy to them in Zürich especially those in need of some skills. Many spoke very good German. Not everyone is  rejected asylum seeker there ( about 15% were from the EU and outside who cannot return for many reasons ) and the people who run the show include the Sans papiers and local Swiss. Their premises have been raided by the police many times.      ( or   in Germany )   
Some Cantons provide a tiny leeway to a permit ( must be able to demonstrate that one is "integrated" and apply a few times for the very limited places for a compassionate permit -   ). This is   although only a handful have obtained them after years on here ( less than 5% get it ). Some find work ( schwarzarbeit ) and those who pay their way through for lodging and other expenses.       
The asylum system here is pretty fair and humane, and in typical Swiss fashion is transparent, logical and embodies procedural fairness with rights as per Administrative Law for review / appeal(s).   
I think the allegation that asylum seekers are charged for rent holds no water.

thread: swissinfo.ch: Why Portuguese seek work in Switzerland
post:
miniMia I can assure you my comment was in no way meant to be unpleasant about Portuguese workers- but pointing out that many, as Gata says, are quite desperate and sadly hugely exploited, by both Swiss and Portuguese employers. We had a similar situation in the UK with many Indian factory owners, especially in the textile trade, vastly exploiting their own - which made it difficult for authorities to act for fear of being accused of racism. This was prevalent in Leicester as the wealthy and experienced ex Ugandan Asians (thrown out by Idi Amin) took over the textile trade in the 70s - and started sweat shops in the town, and also exploiting women and children working at home.   
Portuguese people in my area are well integrated and settled, most of them having arrived in the 70s/80s - many of them with their own businesses here. The village near where I live has 2 Portuguese shops for instance, one is a printer, another a foundry, and several restaurant owners.

thread: Swiss ingenuity strikes again!
post:
This from the current edition of "Horse and Hound" magazine in the UK:       
Horses have made a comeback in more than 120 cities and towns across France and Switzerland. They are used to pull rubbish and recycling collection carts, in parks maintenance and as green school buses.   
Now a hybrid cart  with an   motor that cuts in to help with hills and on difficult terrain  has been developed by Swiss technology company  , with government help.   
Reudi von Neiderhäusen of the Swiss Stud said: We have used six different horses to test the cart, looking at the effect it has on the horse.   
Our research is not concluded, but the response from local people has been very positive. It changes peoples relationship with the street cleaners for the better when they are using a horse rather than a tractor.      
Saw an article about this in the Le Lac free paper some months ago.

thread: Olten, the new Federal Swiss Capital ?  Not really, except for SBB Cargo
post: NO, nobdoy wants to have the Federal Capital in Olten, but SBB CARGO is relocating its HQ from Basel to Olten. The contract about the present location in Basel will terminate in 2014 and the prices for similar locations in Basel no longer are acceptable while the space would be narrow. The price level and the strategic location of Olten makes it THE ideal place for the purpose. The change from entertaining and lively and beautiful Basel to Olten may be a challenge for many of the SBB CARGO folks. But those who relocate may possibly help to "upgrade" Olten a bit. The new HQ will be near to Olten Rail Station. The number of people relocating is around 500.  Some or many of them of course may opt to commute between Basel and Olten. However, many WILL move and some will gradually be "replaced" by people from the Solothurn/Nord-Bern area which includes Biel/Bienne.

thread: Switzerland and PIIGS
post:
Interesting in a way, but the statistics rather cover up the vast differences. While the "active" unemployment-rate in Span and Portugal will get down to the one in Italy, the one in Greece possibly will even rise.    
It works the other way round as well. Companies in Switzerland, and there were and are many, who depend on exports to Italy, Spain, Portugal and Greece (and other such countries) suffered quite heavily and may even have to reduce the personnel.    
You also have to see the difference. Somebody "relieved of his responsibility" at UBS can rely on an intact economy and an intact social structure, but somebody sacked by a Greek bank cannot   
But those "broad unemployment figures" simply are complete rubbish

thread: price comparisons
post:
The "change of law" only is needed in regard to domestic-cartel-agreements. No new law is required in regard to the "UVP - unverbindlicher Verkaufs-Preis -  recommended sales price"  as it is up to the trading company simply to refuse such "recommendations" and in case the suppliers get wild, stop the purchases. There in "Züri-Nord" are two shops dealing with aviation goods who permanently refuse to accept such "recommendations" and at least two major German suppliers very well co-operate. Quite many customers of shops in the Zürich area are (YES, still are! )  Germans, who perfectly well know the few but important products which are cheaper overhere anyway, and also realize within split-seconds when a product is cheaper than in Germany. The German shoppers are important enough that Zürich-City-Police and most of the city-police-units north of Zürich long ago changed the parkometers to accept Euros, of course on the basis of a 1:1 rate, which is nice for the city-finance    What a MediaMarkt chap of MediaMarkt Donaueschingen told me quite a while ago still is true now. Thanks to Japanese-Swiss trade agreements (both country-to-country and company-to-company) many articles in the TV/radio/electronics sector are cheaper here than in Germany but the furniture and some equipment for the stuff in question is cheaper in Germany by up to 60% !  A few months ago, Migros and Coop started to refuse those "recommendations" and only restarted certain imports after those suppliers backed down.    
Why did so many CH retailers accept that nonsense for so long ?   
Very simple, because they had between 25% and 70% out of the add-on profit !    Things only changed when also people farther inland than the usual border-zone saw the savings-potential of a visit to places like Konstanz   
The Konsumentenschutz therefore wants to raise the pressures. Extraordinary circumstances demand extraordinary actions !

thread: Federal Council wants more control re new medical practices
post:
Yes, you are right, different systems are ... different. And some of us feel more comfortable and trust one more than the other. Many people in the Western world choose TCM nowadays, and why not? So if you would prefer to rely on TCM, why don't you, fair enough. A GP in the UK takes 9 years to train (6 years at Uni- 1 year in F1 house officer, then 3 years in F2 for GP training). For specialists, it can be 10 years of more.   
It is true that specialist GP training is not so developed in Switzerland. A school friend of mine was an orthopeadic surgeon all his life, and decided aged 59 to go into general practice, which would not have been possible in the UK.    
But each to their own as regards choice of system we feel more comfortable with, and trust more.

thread: Swiss arrest order against German banking spies
post:
Firstly, he was stupid for even bringing such documents into Germany.   
Secondly, he was even more stupid for telling them that. To be able to prove anything, the customs officials would have had to phone the Finanzamt to verify that these accounts had not been declared, and I doubt that the Finanzamt anwers such queries over the telephone, not even to customs agents. I doubt that the Finanzamt can even access such data in real time. I know from my relatives in Germany that they take months if not years to respond to the simplest of questions, and then still get them wrong. So they would even have had to let the guy go, or confiscated those statements and he would still have had time to do a Selbstanzeige and have it on the desk of the Finanzamt before the customs got their act together.   
And summing up, remember a lot of what you see on TV is set up, often with the intent of scaring people. Quite possibly the guy was an actor doing his job. Do you think he would have signed a moel release to allow footage of him to be put on TV to see for everybody to smirk over if he'd really just been caught in a serious way?   
And finally, I've personally transferred heaps of documents and papers over the border over the years. I've had customs guys look at all sorts of stuff but never my paperwork. They'd probably be too thick to see a bank statment if they saw one.

thread: Reunification of the two Basels ?
post:
All this talk of reunification is just BS.    
Unless it was on our (BL's) terms, I can't see the majority of voters (of whom 60% live in BL) agreeing to reunification.   
Although if it did go through, they'd have to process my tax refund from 2009 at last, which has been held up to date by a dispute between the two half-cantons over an arcane piece of taxation legislation.      As for Wolli's assertion that support for reunification would have grown over 40 years, consider that 60 years ago, support for restricting handgun ownership in the US to police and other (limited) groups stood at over 50% of the population. Today it is around 25% (and that's post-Aurora). If you're someone who thinks that reunification would be the right thing, be aware that public support for "the right things" can wane over time.

thread: FÊTES DE GENEVE - Traffic restrictions along the lakeside
post:
For those of you visiting Geneva for the Fetes !!!   
-----------------------------------------------   
FÊTES DE GENEVE - RESTRICTIONS DE CIRCULATION SUR LES QUAIS AUX DATES SUIVANTES :    
· du vendredi 3 août (20h00) au lundi 6 août 2012 (4h00) ; 
· du vendredi 10 août (20h00) au lundi 13 août 2012 (4h00).   
La Mission permanente de la Suisse auprès de l'Office des Nations Unies et des autres organisations internationales à Genève communique ci-après les informations reçues de la Police de Genève concernant le sujet mentionné en exergue.    
Dimportantes restrictions de circulation et de stationnement seront prises sur les deux rives du lac aux dates susmentionnées en raison de la tenue des Fêtes de Genève. Aussi, la Police recommande aux visiteurs demprunter les transports publics et prie les usagers de se conformer à la signalisation mise en place à cet effet.        
Du vendredi 3 août, 20h00, au lundi 6 août, 4h00, les quais seront fermés à la circulation (entre la rue de Lausanne et la rue des Alpes sur la Rive droite et entre la place des Marronniers et le Quai général-Guisan sur la Rive gauche). Le Pont du Mont-Blanc restera quant à lui ouvert à la circulation.   
Le dimanche 5 août, les quais Gustave-Ador et de Cologny seront interdits à la circulation sur la voie côté lac entre 9h30 et 16h30 (journée Slow-up). La circulation sera également interdite sur la route de Thonon depuis Vésenaz en direction de Genève. La circulation restera autorisée dans le sens Genève-Vésenaz.       
Du vendredi 10 août, 20h00, au lundi 13 août, 4h00, les quais seront fermés à la circulation (entre la rue de Lausanne et la rue des Alpes sur la Rive droite et entre la place des Marronniers et le Quai général-Guisan sur la Rive gauche). Le Pont du Mont-Blanc restera quant à lui ouvert à la circulation la majeure partie du temps (seule une voie côté lac sera fermée).        
· Dès 17h00, laxe rue de Chantepoulet, rue du Mont-Blanc, pont du Mont-Blanc, quai Général-Guisan, rue de Versonnex, avenue Pictet-de-Rochemont, sera fermé à la circulation jusquau dimanche 12 août, 4h00.    
· Dès 18h00, le Quai Gustave-Ador sera fermé à la circulation entre la place De-Traînant et la place des Marronniers jusquau lundi 13 août, 4h00.       
Le samedi 4 août, de 20h00 à 24h00, (petit feu d'artifice) l'accès au parking du Mont-Blanc sera possible.   
Du samedi 11 août, 17h00, au dimanche 12 août, 4h00, (grand feu d'artifice), l'accès au parking du Mont-Blanc sera autorisé depuis la rive gauche (côté amont) uniquement. La sortie du parking se fera seulement en direction de la rive gauche (côté aval).   
Le dimanche 5 août, de 9h30 à 16h30 (Slow up), laccès au parking de Genève-Plage ne sera possible que depuis les Eaux-Vives ou la rampe de Cologny.   
Du vendredi 3 août, 20h00, au lundi 6 août, 4h00, et du vendredi 10 août, 20h00, au lundi 13 août, 4h00, l'accès au parking se trouvant sous le palais Wilson ne pourra se faire que depuis la rue Gautier (rue située devant l'entrée principale de l'hôtel Président).   
Les parkings de Rive, Saint-Antoine, Villereuse, Eaux-Vives 2000, Thalberg et Cornavin seront accessibles pendant toute la durée des festivités.

thread: Another initiative launched ( criminal foreigners )
post:
The rightwing Swiss People’s Party has launched a second initiative to deport foreign criminals, this time to define exactly under which circumstances they can and cannot be deported.   
The initiative text, which extends to five articles over three pages, was accepted on Tuesday by the Federal Chancellery. The party has until  , to collect the 100,000 signatures required to force a nationwide vote on the issue.   
In a statement, the People’s Party said it had launched the initiative because the government is taking too long to implement its first initiative, which won a majority in a nationwide vote in November 2010.   
The initiative text specifies that the Swiss law would have primacy over international law.

thread: USA visa-waiver problem SOLVED
post:
It became known today that a new agreement is in place, which includes 
> maximum visa-free stay in the USA =  90 days 
> the automatic exchange of DNAs + fingerprints is limited to crimes with  
a possible punishment of more than 3 years 
> both countries will correct, block or delete entries upon justified demands 
> the USA in case of need first has to ask whether CH has required data, and if yes get a reference-number and then have to place an application-request 
> there will be an improved and extended co-operation in regard to anti-terrorism programs   
So, all in all, quite many but quite useful compromises

An explanation in today's L'Express newspaper. At the end of 2011, the Greek health insurances had unpaid debts in Switzerland 0f 12.8 million CHF, for operations they had given permission to go ahead and had agreed to pay for. Apparently the debt for unpaid medical treatment in CH for other EU countries amounts to 186 million CHF. The difference is apparently that payments from other EU countries does eventually get paid, with long delays- whereas Greece has just stopped making any payments.   
So what is the Swiss health system (us) supposed to do? Can we really take such losses 'on the chin' and just raise our premiums even more to cover for this?

thread: Spanish capitalists invade Switzerland
post:
- 
The strategy to "diversify" the country's export markets was started in 1948, a time when what later became the "Eurozone" made up some 80% of the export market. Switzerland however already in the 1940ies and 50ies had a strong customerbase in the Arab World, in Africa, in South Asia and in East Asia, but exactly those markets ARE price-sensitive. You may add countries like Israel, where the customers before the PEG deserted the Swiss exporters and now are back.  The emerging markets may be "cash-flush" but of course compare the prices.       - 
Switzerland introduced those restrictions against NON-EU professionals as part of the Bilaterals with the EU. There is no way to "looseneing the permit restrictions on non EU professionals" as the signed treaties are definite.  Switzerland cannot "tighten restrictions on EU nationals" due to the various treaties.       - 
To say it again, some 80% of the Swiss exports were to the "Eurozone neighbours" back around 1950.  NOBODY in Switzerland regards the PEG as THE long-term solution. But it at present is necessary as long as the financial markets are in chaos.       
And here a map   
which shows you where Switzerland is !  Switzerland is "deep in the heart of Europe" .  Many of its export markets are less than an hour or two away from the exporter. People there speak the same language, share the same culture,      
and you of course will see the Maghreb below left, and may argue that this is NOT Europe, and many Europeans may agree with you. But I will never forget when I on visit to London discussed things with three Sudanese and told them that as half Algerian ....etc....etc ..... but was corrrected them, saying that for them the three Maghreb countries ARE Europe !   YES, Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia are A) as strictly and totally linked to Europe but as members of the "Mediterranean Partnership" together with Egypt, Israel, Lebanon and Jordan also bound into Europe as much as Switzerland. In case of Switzerland you have to add that Switzerland is full member of the Council of Europe (Europa-Rat), a rather underestimated organisation AND more then 20 European organisations.  Switzerland is more closely integrated into Europe than Britain. Switzerland is a full member of both Schengen & Dublin, which brings lots of advantages but of course also obligations

thread: The Elite is not integrated...
post:
I guess I should post a little more on topic. I live in Zug (first lived here 5 years ago, moved to Zurich for 4 years, and came back), and I've integrated pretty well. I have expat friends here, but I have local friends as well. I speak German pretty well and don't have a real problem with the local dialects. I don't know if I qualify as a wealthy foreigner, but I am definitely a well-paid expat.   
I've even been known to leave my neighbors notes (though I sign them rather than anonymously send them, so I guess I'm not all the way yet).   
Maybe the difference is that, rather than coming in on an expat bubble, I accepted a job at the equivalent of about 60k per year in order to get my foot in the door and get the permit issue sorted. Once that was done, I worked my way up, but the first two roles I had (both in this canton) I worked almost entirely with Swiss people, and thus a lot of my friends come from that group. I know which bars the locals hang out at (hint: it's not Pickwick), and I've more or less figured out the "proper" mix of American infrormality and spontaneity with Swiss planning and structure. Still working on the volume issue, but I'm getting there.   
The key to my integration is, in my opinion, to seek out change. Look for what's different, rather than trying to find ways to make it the same. Abolishing those international schools so that kids have to learn German and parents have to interact with Swiss parents might help, too.   But it's not really that hard, and not integrating sort of makes being abroad defeat the purpose unless you're just looking for bragging rights with the hillbillies back home, so I don't get why it's considered such an issue.

He joined EMS Chemie as a lawyer (legal advisor) and when the company went belly up, arranged some outside money and took the company over and managed a successful restart. He thereafter usually took over ailing industrial companies and modernized them. Interesting is that EMS-Chemie was the first company using the then new EUR-1 preferential documents for shipments to EU countries !  His conglomerate already in the 80ies expanded to the Austrian and the German side of the Rhein by purchasing factories there. His group also, by agreements with the governments in Cairo and Delhi gave "stagaire" jobs for a year to thousands of Egyptians and Indians, which were badly paid by Swiss standards but splendid by Egyptian and Indian standards   
Well, this is different from the image he himself placed into the media and not really what might be expected from the chief-Blocherite   
**************************************************  ************************       Yes, he starts to look OLD !  which would be no problem for somebody  with a different approach. Nicolas Hayek until his death made a good  picture, in spite of showing his age. The SVP-Guru however has a bit of a  problem with a role of an "elder statesmen"

thread: Switzerland is not cheap!
post:
Not to put too fine a point on it but...what are you smoking?   Value? Hotels? we paid 375chf/night for one TINY hotel room in a pretty run of the mill place, no frills and not scenic. Sure, there was breakfast, but if you're not much of a breakfast person, this isn't a big deal. I'm pretty certain I could get a larger and more luxurious hotel room in the Ritz with a park view in NYC for less.      Not with the iPhone they aren't. I'm paying about the same.      LOL. I laughed so hard, tears came to my eyes.       Oh, the F they are! I'm still buying chicken, giant gorgeous organic grass-fed, whatever chickens at such cheap prices I can't stop myself! Not on your life (and Boston is not considered one of the cheap parts of the US) are groceries 'about the same'. No.       What wage difference. The company is actually paying my husband 10k /more/ in the US. Unless you're some sort of wage slave in the US who gets promoted to a 100k or more chf pay packet in Switzerland, the win is simply not there.    
The skew is far more than simply 'exchange' rate inequities.

thread: "Buchpreis-Bindung" sent down the drain
post:
Until a certain point I can understand why far away from the publishers and big number distribution channel an item costs more, also much more.   
What we have in CH however is that il Corriere della Sera, L'Espresso, Il Panorama and all of them cost a lot more, having the same or even lower transportation costs. They have the same price in Chiasso as they probably have at Basel, but far more than at Domodossola or Battipaglia.        The list is longer in fact, but not by much (and some have the same owner).   
So in some regions (Ticino e.g.) you don't have the newspapers you once had (s.th. like 3 if you don't count free stuff and the weekly newspaper Il Caffè della Domenica what is the best one imho).   
So offer is restricted.   
Another problem is the Swiss Post Office and letter delivery (extremely slow). That's why I cancelled my Corriere del Ticino-abo this year after decades (besides that I didn't really like it - but what else could I have read?), having the newspaper only in the afternoon (and I have no time to read in the evening) being delivered with my letters.

thread: Naturalisation vote raises emotions
Row erupts over Geneva cross-border workers
post:
Yes the calculation is on a different basis but I believe it comes down to about 80% of the tax remaining in Geneva. France as a country only gets around 20% which is not that much I believe.  I agree it is an advantageous for the villages in the Haute-Savoie as contrary to income tax the kickbacks are not going to Paris but to a large part straight to the villages. But even then, the average amount per frontalier paid by Geneva to France works out at only around 1,000 euro I think per frontalier per year.  Not a bad deal at all for Geneva in my opinion. By sending its workforce back to France every evening, Geneva can continue to keep building only half the houses it would have to build otherwise in order to keep up with the demographic growth.    
But Canton Vaud is different to Geneva, I believe you are only taxed in France if you work as a frontalier in Vaud.

thread: Swiss justice Minister: Foreign residents should learn a Swiss language
post:
Certainly one should speak the local language to the point of functionality.   
However, integration is another matter altogether.    
I am an expat - or (trailing spouse of a) guest worker if you prefer - but not an immigrant. My stay here is temporary; we came because my husband was asked to do a job. We will not stay beyond that job, however many years that may be. Switzerland is not my home.    
I try to be a good Auslander. I speak German. I'm respectful, I know the laws and obey them. But true integration is a two-way street. If integration is really a goal, not only do Auslanders have to learn to be 'Swiss-like', but the Swiss have to be prepared to actually accept Auslanders as part of their society. And the latter part is very much missing.    
Let's be honest - parallel societies are created because Swiss society is closed to outsiders. You can only bang your head against a closed door for so long before you give up and find another way.

thread: A little snippet from the news this morning.
post: If you are asking why there has been a rise in the number of people bringing large quantities of physical valuables into Switzerland, then unfortunately you must look at the source of such items. The undeveloped world is (as always) going through a turbulent period, and in such periods wealthy people fear for their wealth. In some of these countries, government ministers are almost guaranteed to be embezzling money. Companies abuse the environment and human rights to make profits. Wealthy people may be prevented from transferring large sums of money outside the country by capital controls. In all of the above situations, it is much easier for people to get their wealth out of the country by using gold, diamonds, etc. than through traceable channels.

thread: A swiss "DSK"-like affair in Geneva?
post:
A genevese politician is involved in a mini-scandal relayed (way too much i my opinion) by the media in the romandie. A good case to compare cultural differences based on reactions to an incident involving a politcian.      Mark Muller is the cantonal minister responsible for infrastructure in Geneva. He is from the Liberal/Radical party.     : on the 31st december Mark Muller was having fun in the personnel WC with a waitress of the bar. The barman and also manager asked him what he was doing there (according to the barman he didn't know or recognized Mark Muller). After Muller left the scene, the barman rebuked the waitress. He then went outside to smoke a cigarette. He was then attacked from behind by a man who was beating him and shouting "you humiliated my friend, I'm gonna kill you" and a fight followed between Muller and the barman. The barman filed a complain and the incident is under investigation. 
His party the PLR is asking him to resign.   
So what is the most chocking thing? 
 - the "sex" in the toilet 
 - the beating/fight 
 - the party asking for resignation   
I find this is taking way too much place in the swiss-romand media and there are far more serious problems for citizens that should catch the attention of both media and politicians. 
This is a typical " " displaying a real problem (corruption, amateurism, clientelism,...) of genevese politicians.

thread: Vote on minimum wage- what would you do?
post:
So by your logic being on welfare is better than working in a low pay job?    
Minimum wage will push more people on social security because it will price out workers that would normally be worth less than what the minimum wage pays (i.e. too old, disabled and disadvantaged). There is nothing wrong with a person who is disabled asking to be paid less than a person who gets minimum wage. The disabled person is entitled to a job as much as anyone else, provided they have some form of voluntary advantage over an able bodied person. At a minimum wage of 22 francs per hour the disabled person cannot be priced at that amount if an able bodied person is priced at that also. That means that in a 100% of cases that are not charities, the disabled person will never have the opportunity to work for pay. The same goes for people who are too old i.e. 70 years old. A 70 years old might be happy to be paid a small amount just to get out of the house and out of the wife's hair. With a minimum wage he can forget it, no one will hire him at a price they pay anyone else. Because there are more risks and costs associated with hiring someone that is 'too old', the minimum wage will price these people out of the market. The minimum wage is incredibly discriminatory, it prices out everyone who is not worth the minimum wage and thats usually the forgotten members of our society.    
A problem Switzerland often faces is how hard it is for older workers to find work and/or re enter the workforce. Well thats because of the extra costs associated with hiring older workers. Thats the fault of government creating the extra and unnecessary insurance costs, not business. Older workers are priced out of the market, because they are not on an equal playing field as it is being distorted by bureaucrats saying that business should pay more insurance for these workers.     
Therefore if minimum wage prices certain people out of the workforce, than more people drift towards welfare, This in turn then causes more pressure on existing taxes which means more and additional costs on business and workers. Its a terrible cycle that ends where the Eurozone and Western world are right now. If minimum wage were the holy grail that it is made up to be, then Switzerland would not have the highest living standards in the world as well as pay some of the highest salaries.   
If I may ask, what happened to your 'savings for a rainy day'? Savings are what is supposed to supplement social security. I mean you have had the opportunity to work for 45 years!. Or am I missing something?      I would imagine with such a comment that you have never run a business in your life. Many businesses struggle out there and many will fail completely. There is no such thing as a decent wage. Wages should be priced by the market without interference, because thats the only way a price or wage can be calculated. You cannot calculate a wage based on what some person sitting in an office in the capital says. A businesses wage costs isnt just a function of the cost of labour (in a perfect world it would be and we should all wish it was so!) it is also payroll costs, regulatory costs, social security, insurance etc etc. Thats what makes employing people expensive. I promise you, there are many businesses out there that would prefer to pay those inputs to the worker instead of the government, lawyers and insurance companies. Unfortunately those costs have to come out of somebody's pocket and often it is shared one way or another between the customer, employees and business owner.   
You should note that almost all startups lose money in the first few years while they build up to pay for their initially start up costs. So profitabililty initially is irrelevant, as for most it is only a dream.
