thread: Why is Switzerland pro-whaling ?
post:
Ocean conservation is a subject in which I have a keen interest. I can say that this thread doesn't really surprise me. This is not the first time that Switzerland has used its voting rights in organisations that decide matters of the ocean to side with the "underdog". Most people could not be blamed for being baffled by this - after all Switzerland has no ocean.   
Why does it do this? I can only make two guesses (someone please correct me if I have missed something here)   
1. Siding with a country with an unpopular opinion (e.g. Japan or Norway on the issue of whaling) might be a way to gain favour from that country in return for that country supporting Switzerland on another issue (e.g. political horse trading).   
2. Where there is a matter of more direct national interest - for example if a Swiss company were supplying something to a company or industry which might be affected by the issue, for example (purely hypothetical!!) if they were supplying harpoons to shoot the whales they might be keen to protect their customers' ability to use (and therefore buy) the harpoons.   
I recall a case a while back where Switzerland opposed the protection of an endangered species of seal. I was puzzled about it and did some research on it. Turns out that a couple of these seals exist in a children's zoo in Rapperswil. Would that really be enough of a reason to oppose such a move?   
The mind boggles sometimes...

thread: Swiss tax system - time for a reform?
post:
Actually it wasn't a proposal to create a unified tax system at all. Did you RTFA?   
Even if there were a centrally processed tax system (instead of 4600 different tax departments) it would not mean that the money would have to be allocated differently - the collection/administration of taxes and the allocation and eventual spending of them are different issues.   
I see this as a first step - simply streamlining the process a little and trying to remove some of the administrative overhead. It's not an earth shattering proposal to covert to the system of government used in other countries.   
This is Switzerland after all - each small step takes time.

thread: Popular votes: 24th September
post:
Hi NickJ,   
I admit that that all sounds well and good in theory. However there have been cases of some now semi-prominent people in Swiss society who were originally asylum seekers without papers. Some of them went through two or three appeals (under the much older rules) before being accepted to stay. The no campaign had some posters up with their photos and their stories.       [swissinfo.ch] tells the story of a man who left Turkey. It says that even today he is unable to talk about the abuse he suffered, which is a common condition among those who have undergone extremely stressful situations. I'm sure readers of many tabloid newspapers would pronounce such excuses as complete BS, but the fact is this guy's application took four years, but now he is allowed to stay. The video tells the story of his struggle to integrate. Would his case be considered "uncooperative" and see him deported or jailed under the new rules?   
It's a sad fact that yes, they do have to be housed and fed during their application period. But the even sadder fact is that the application process takes a very long time. I'm sure improvement could be made in this process. I note also that out of the total number of asylum applications, very few are actually approved. Still, at least when we house them and feed them we do so without interning them in camps in the desert or offshore islands as is the case in Australia (not happy, John).   
I do agree with you however that if the same vote were put to the public in many western European countries the result would be the same. But those other countries are supposed to elect politicians that do their homework on these issues, rather than asking a somewhat uninformed public for their opinion.   
Anyway, looks like the results are in and here's   [swissinfo.ch]. 68 percent voted yes. Interesting, exactly the same number for both the asylum and the foreigner vote - I wonder if voters had trouble telling the two apart? Here's a small quote:      Now there's a surprise    
Here's an interesting question. Imagine if there were a vote which asked "Should we refuse to take any asylum seekers whatsoever?". Imagine if this vote were put to the people in Switzerland, or any other European country. Would the electorate, if given the chance, close their borders completely to those fleeing persecution, just as the Swiss turned away Jews at the German border duing World War 2?   
Lob, small correction on the ammendments to the asylum law - it's actually five times since 1984 that ammendments were approved by voting, but the total number of ammendments is actually nine.
